colors = ['#DC143C', '#fa9b98', '#0d8c68', '#95c5b1', '#4169E1', '#adc3ff', '#595959', '#c4c4c4']
x=bmw.transmission.value_counts()

fig,ax=plt.subplots(figsize=(10,6))
ax.barh([0],x.values[0],height = 0.7, color = 'black', alpha = 0.7)
plt.text(-1400,0, 'Semi-Auto', {'font': 'Serif','weight':'bold','Size': '16','style':'normal', 'color':'black'}, alpha = 0.7)
plt.text(2500,0, '43%',{'font':'Serif', 'weight':'bold','size':'16','color':'black'}, alpha = 0.7)

ax.barh([1],x.values[1],height = 0.7, color = '#b20710', alpha = 0.7)
plt.text(-1400,1, 'Automatic', {'font': 'Serif','weight':'bold','Size': '16','style':'normal', 'color':'black'}, alpha = 0.7)
plt.text(2500,1, '33%',{'font':'Serif', 'weight':'bold','size':'16','color':'black'}, alpha = 0.7)

ax.barh([2],x.values[2],height = 0.7, color = colors[2], alpha = 0.7)
plt.text(-1400,2, 'Manual', {'font': 'Serif','weight':'bold','Size': '16','style':'normal', 'color':'black'}, alpha = 0.7)
plt.text(2500,2, '24%',{'font':'Serif', 'weight':'bold','size':'16','color':'black'}, alpha = 0.7)

fig.patch.set_facecolor('#f6f5f5')
ax.set_facecolor('#f6f5f5')

plt.text(-1150,3, 'How Type of Gear-Box Is Distributed? ' ,{'font': 'Serif', 'Size': '25','weight':'bold', 'color':'black'}, alpha = 0.9)

plt.text(-1150,2.7, 'Looks like Gear-Box of most of the BMW cars are of Semi-auto', 
        {'font':'Serif', 'size':'12.5','color': 'black'})


ax.axes.get_xaxis().set_visible(False)
ax.axes.get_yaxis().set_visible(False)
ax.spines['bottom'].set_visible(False)
ax.spines['left'].set_visible(True)
ax.spines['right'].set_visible(False)
ax.spines['top'].set_visible(False)
fig.show()
source.0e433cb3:
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize = (10,4), dpi = 90)
ax.set_facecolor('#f6f5f5')
fig.patch.set_facecolor('#f6f5f5')

a = bmw.fuelType.value_counts()
colors = ['#b20710','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey']
ax.bar(x = a.index, height = a.values, color = colors, alpha = 0.9)

# Create labels
label = a.values.tolist()
 
# Text on the top of each bar
for i in range(len(label)):
    x = i  - 0.35
    y = (i+18)/2 + label[i]
    x = x-0.08
    y = y + 52
    ax.text(x,y, '{}'.format(a.values[i]),{'font': 'serif', 'weight': 'normal', 'color': 'black', 'fontsize': 10}, alpha = 0.8)

#ax.set_xticks(a.values)
ax.text(-1,8000, 'Fuel Type | Type of Engine Fuel', {'font': 'serif', 'color': 'black', 'fontsize': 18, 'weight':'bold'},alpha = 0.9 )
ax.text(-1,7500, 'well it seems like most number of cars have Diesel Engine. ', {'font': 'serif', 'color': 'black', 'fontsize': 12,},alpha = 0.8)

for loc in ['left','right','top','bottom']:
    ax.spines[loc].set_visible(False)
    
ax.set_xticklabels(a.index, {'font': 'serif', 'color': 'black', 'fontsize': 8,'weight':'bold'}, alpha = 0.8)
ax.axes.get_yaxis().set_visible(False)
fig.show()
source.f66995ff:
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize = (15,6))
ax.set_facecolor('#f6f5f5')
fig.patch.set_facecolor('#f6f5f5')

a = bmw.model.value_counts()
colors = ['#b20710','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey','grey']
ax.bar(x = a.index, height = a.values, color = colors, alpha = 0.9)

# Create labels
label = a.values.tolist()
 
# Text on the top of each bar
for i in range(len(label)):
    x = i  - 0.35
    y = (i+18)/2 + label[i]
    x = x-0.08
    y = y + 52
    ax.text(x,y, '{}'.format(a.values[i]),{'font': 'serif', 'weight': 'normal', 'color': 'black', 'fontsize': 10}, alpha = 0.8)

#ax.set_xticks(a.values)
ax.text(-1,2800, 'Distribution of Model', {'font': 'serif', 'color': 'black', 'fontsize': 18, 'weight':'bold'},alpha = 0.9 )
ax.text(-1,2700, ' Most of the cars are of have model 3 Series . ', {'font': 'serif', 'color': 'black', 'fontsize': 12,},alpha = 0.8)

for loc in ['left','right','top','bottom']:
    ax.spines[loc].set_visible(False)
    
ax.set_xticklabels(a.index, {'font': 'serif', 'color': 'black', 'fontsize': 8,'weight':'bold'}, alpha = 0.8)
ax.axes.get_yaxis().set_visible(False)
fig.show()
source.3850189b:
fig =  plt.figure(figsize = (15,6))
fig.patch.set_facecolor('#f5f6f6')


                                                   
gs = fig.add_gridspec(2,3)
gs.update(wspace=0.2,hspace= 0.2)

ax0 = fig.add_subplot(gs[0,0])
ax1 = fig.add_subplot(gs[0,1])
ax2 = fig.add_subplot(gs[0,2])
ax3 = fig.add_subplot(gs[1,0])
ax4 = fig.add_subplot(gs[1,1])
ax5 = fig.add_subplot(gs[1,2])

axes=[ax0,ax1,ax2,ax3,ax4,ax5]
for ax in axes:
    ax.set_facecolor('#f5f6f6')
    ax.tick_params(axis='x',
                   labelsize = 12, which = 'major',
                   direction = 'out',pad = 2,
                   length = 1.5)
    ax.tick_params(axis='y', colors= 'black')
    ax.axes.get_yaxis().set_visible(False)
    
    for loc in ['left', 'right', 'top', 'bottom']:
        ax.spines[loc].set_visible(False)


        
cols = bmw.select_dtypes(exclude = 'object').columns

sns.kdeplot(x = bmw[cols[0]],color="green",fill=True,ax = ax0)
sns.kdeplot(x = bmw[cols[1]],color="red",fill=True,ax = ax1)
sns.kdeplot(x = bmw[cols[2]],color="blue",fill=True,ax = ax2)
sns.kdeplot(x = bmw[cols[3]],color="black",fill=True,ax = ax3)
sns.kdeplot(x = bmw[cols[4]],color="pink",fill=True,ax = ax4)
sns.kdeplot(x = bmw[cols[5]],color="green",fill=True,ax = ax5)

fig.text(0.2,0.98,"Univariate Analysis on Numerical Columns:",**{'font':'serif', 'size':18,'weight':'bold'}, alpha = 1)
fig.text(0.1,0.90,"  As we can see there is so much otliers present in the numerical columns:",**{'font':'serif', 'size':12,'weight':'bold'}, alpha = 1)
fig.show()

source.aa4d36da:
It is the improvement to R squared. The problem/drawback with R2 is that as the features increase, the value of R2 also increases which gives the illusion of a good model. So the Adjusted R2 solves the drawback of R2. It only considers the features which are important for the model and shows the real improvement of the model.
Adjusted R2 is always lower than R2!

source.c85a707e:
In the most simple words, Linear Regression is the supervised Machine Learning model in which the model finds the best fit linear line between the independent and dependent variable i.e it finds the linear relationship between the dependent and independent variable.
Linear Regression is of two types: Simple and Multiple.
Simple Linear Regression is where only one independent variable is present and the model has to find the linear relationship of it with the dependent variable.
Whereas, In Multiple Linear Regression there are more than one independent variables for the model to find the relationship.
